ad_creative_body: President Trump has made enough broken promises. Now, it's time for a change.
President Trump has made enough broken promises. Now, it's time for a change.

America is in a time of crisis. But we can’t just build back to the way things were before these crises — we have to build back better. 

If you’re ready to elect a president who will fight for working people, protect our environment for the generations to come, and work to heal our deepest divisions, add your name right now.
The only constant in Trump's White House is chaos.

Every single day since Donald Trump was elected, we’ve been looking forward to this – finally, Election Day is here.

Take just a minute right now to confirm your polling place, and then get out and vote Trump out on Tuesday, Nov. 3!
We cannot afford four more years of broken promises.

The USPS is one of the most essential services the government provides. Because of it, every household in this country can receive mail every day — whether you live in a large coastal city or a small midwestern town. And the USPS is one of the largest employers of veterans in the country, giving folks who have served our country access to good-paying union jobs. 

But Republicans have been attacking the USPS for years. And now, Trump’s hand-picked postmaster general is trying to cut USPS services for Americans and cut benefits for post office workers. This is unacceptable. We must elect Joe Biden and Democrats and save the USPS. Sign on if you agree.

Voting in GA is as easy as returning your ballot. You can do it today!

Just follow these simple steps:

#1. Fill out the ballot.

#2. Place your ballot in inner envelope. Then place inner envelope in outer envelope.

#3. Sign outer envelope.

#4. Return your ballot by: mail, dropbox (if available), or drop it off in person.

Find out more at iwillvote.com/ga.

President Trump knows that he can’t trust the Lamestream media to report accurately, so, as one of his most reliable advisors, he’s asked us to reach out to YOU to get YOUR input on his America First Agenda by taking our Official America First Policy Survey.

Please take our Official America First Policy Survey by 11:59 PM TONIGHT to make sure your input is received.

Here’s the truth - If you want your children to inherit the blessings that generations of Americans have fought and died to secure, then we must devote everything we have toward victory in 2020.

This is the only way we can save the America we love – and drain the Washington Swamp once and for all.

Please contribute ANY AMOUNT in the NEXT HOUR to our Drain the Swamp Fund and to get on the list my team hands me.
President Trump needs you now more than ever. Vote November 3rd.

“It’s hard for everyone. It’s emotional for everyone. It’s weird for everyone. But there are communities that this is hitting harder and they deserve that recognition and assistance.” ✨

Meet Isabella, an IRC Dallas staff member who is helping low-income and refugee families —who are being hit hardest —survive the #Coronavirus pandemic.

Working alone for safety, Isabella distributes a week’s worth of food, including fresh vegetables from our New Roots garden, to IRC clients. Every week, she serves over 100 families in the community.

This is just one of the many ways we’re responding to #COVID19 - safely. We plan on doing this work as long as closures take place and for as long as possible. Together, step by step, we will get through this.

Women make history when they find each other. Especially this past year, they used our apps to connect and collaborate with one another. In this chapter of Women x Women, we asked Chrissie and Gladys Lam — a mother-daughter duo behind Love Is Project — to tell us what women supporting other women means to them and how that support has positively affected their lives.

Love Is Project partners with female artisans around the world to create unique bracelets that represent their culture and heritage. Every purchase means financial independence, water and food security for artisans and their families and education for their kids.

“To be able to see the impact of our work is really inspiring — I get WhatsApp updates from artisans all the time. We’re seeing the improvements in these women’s lives, like having them be able to send their kids to school or build a community garden. So, our growth is exciting because we know we’ll be able to touch and positively affect more lives.” - Chrissie Lam, CEO of Love Is Project

Join us in celebrating Women’s History Month by honoring powerful women in your life. 

Directed by Gemma Warren

Women make history when they find each other. Especially this past year, they used our apps to connect and collaborate with one another. In this chapter of Women x Women, we asked Meet Me At The Altar — a band who is redefining punk rock with their unique take on the genre — to tell us what women supporting other women means to them and how that support has positively affected their lives.

“I feel like the best way we empower women is just being that band for them and being that representation that we have been looking for, for so many years.” - Ada, Drummer

“We're super outspoken about the lack of diversity and representation. And I think that's really good for people to know that we're aware of it and we're talking about it.” - Téa, Guitarist 

“We get so many DMs on Instagram from people being like, ‘Thank you so much. I wanted representation and I never had it, but now I do. And I'm so grateful for you guys.’ It’s been really rewarding to read all of them.” - Edith, Singer

👏Clapping for our own health workers and humanitarian heroes👏 

Here's a brand new update from our teams around the world working to stop the spread of #COVID19 on the front line of the pandemic: 

👏 Our staff in Serbia helped install toilets in Obrenovac, an asylum center in Belgrade. The center is currently home to 1,200 people despite only having room for 300. Our team managed to carry out the government request in just 7 days. 
👏 In Greece, IRC's Shadi is an Environmental Health Assistant and was part of the team who built a health triage center in Moria camp on the island of Lesvos. He is participating in a COVID-19 training led by MSF and will be looking after the environmental health on the islands such as managing garbage collection - safely. 
👏 When the Venezuela border closed, many individuals became stuck at the Colombian border with Venezuela, waiting to cross through the irregular pathways. The IRC quickly assembled a team of nurses and doctors to do triage, as well as provide medical assistance to those with COVID symptoms and refer individuals according to the protocols established by the Colombian Ministry of Health. 
👏 In Mexico, we have launched - together with local authorities and civil society partners - a public health awareness and psycho-social support campaign for people in shelters at the US-Mexico border in Ciudad Juárez. The initiative will include sessions on transmission as well as protective and preventive measures, signs and symptoms of the virus, where to access help and support, reinforcement of public health best practices and the distribution of hygiene kits. 

So proud of our staff. Please join us in thanking all IRC health workers for their vital efforts combating the #coronavirus in crisis zones worldwide!

“I am a musician. I am a bull rider. I am a technologist. I’m engaged. I’m a stepparent. I’m your neighbor. And there are many other people like me.”

For Lee (they/them), coming out means defining the person they always wanted to be, and showing up as their authentic self no matter what environment they’re in.

“I am very proud to be trans. To be non-binary. Because I think people think we only exist in these particular spaces and that is not the case.” 

We’re all better off when we understand each other more. Learn about non-binary people and their community and how you can support them through resources from The National Center for Transgender Equality: https://transequality.org/issues/resources/understanding-non-binary-people-how-to-be-respectful-and-supportive

Women make history when they find each other. Especially this past year, they used our apps to connect and collaborate with one another. In this chapter of Women x Women, we asked Chrissie and Gladys Lam — a mother-daughter duo behind Love Is Project — to tell us what women supporting other women means to them and how that support has positively affected their lives.

Love Is Project partners with female artisans around the world to create unique bracelets that represent their culture and heritage. Every purchase means financial independence, water and food security for artisans and their families and education for their kids.

“To be able to see the impact of our work is really inspiring — I get WhatsApp updates from artisans all the time. We’re seeing the improvements in these women’s lives, like having them be able to send their kids to school or build a community garden. So, our growth is exciting because we know we’ll be able to touch and positively affect more lives.” - Chrissie Lam, CEO of Love Is Project

Join us in celebrating Women’s History Month by honoring powerful women in your life. 

Directed by Gemma Warren

“It’s hard for everyone. It’s emotional for everyone. It’s weird for everyone. But there are communities that this is hitting harder and they deserve that recognition and assistance.” ✨

Meet Isabella, an IRC Dallas staff member who is helping low-income and refugee families —who are being hit hardest —survive the #Coronavirus pandemic.

Working alone for safety, Isabella distributes a week’s worth of food, including fresh vegetables from our New Roots garden, to IRC clients. Every week, she serves over 100 families in the community.

This is just one of the many ways we’re responding to #COVID19 - safely. We plan on doing this work as long as closures take place and for as long as possible. Together, step by step, we will get through this.

✊ Women’s rights activists in Uganda are taking down the patriarchy. ✊ ⁠⠀
⁠⠀
Meet some of these activists we’re proud to work with as part of the IRC’s Listen Up program with U.S. Department of State:  Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration - which aims to both listen *to* women and girls who are displaced (instead of deciding *for* them) and to amplify their voices - South Sudanese refugees and Ugandan change-makers are working together so that women and girls can live free from violence. ⁠⠀
⁠⠀
✊ Jemimah Sadia, a refugee from South Sudan, is the founder of Togoleta, a women’s activist group in Bidi Bidi camp (the second largest in the world) that provides counseling to refugees in the camp to prevent violence and help women and girls recover from abuse. Building up her grass-roots women’s movement has been a huge part of her life since she found safety in Uganda.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
✊Grace Muuduru has been standing up for women since she was at school. She remembers confronting boys bullying her friend and telling them: ‘One day this girl could be President!’ Today, she works for COSMESS, a women’s rights group in northern Uganda that helps both refugees and Ugandan women.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
✊ Jackie Letaru is a teacher in Uganda who challenges sexism in her classroom. “I’m a feminist, a strong one,” she said. She cultivates a culture where girls know their value and are respected. “One of my responsibilities at the school is being a leader to girls. Education is a key to their success.” ⁠⠀
⁠⠀
✊ Foni Grace fled war in South Sudan to Uganda in 2016, taking her two daughters with her to Bidi Bidi camp. Today, she’s a member of Togoleta, the group founded by Jemimah (above). “My work for women will be permanent. I feel I have to continue with my work in activism.” ⁠⠀
⁠⠀
Women and girls, and particularly those living as refugees, are not passive recipients of humanitarian aid, but activists with their own ideas and motivations. At the IRC, we are proud to work alongside activists like Jemimah, Grace, Jackie and Foni to make equality a reality. ⁠⠀
⁠⠀
More on their stories here: https://www.rescue.org/article/these-womens-rights-activists-uganda-are-demanding-better?edme=true

In this chapter of Women x Women, Meet Me At The Altar presents “Hit Like a Girl” - an original song with lyrics inspired by fan comments on the Facebook App and Instagram, powered by a collective love for music. 

“I feel like the best way we empower women is just being that band for them and being that representation that we have been looking for for so many years.” - Ada, Drummer 

“If you're a woman, you can do anything you set your mind to, no matter what anyone says. So we really wanted to put that in this song and let our female fans know that they rock! The lyrics speak about support and being there for each other. Women need to really stick together, because it’s us against the world!” - Edith, Singer

“We wanted to make an anthem for female empowerment. So 'Hit Like a Girl' is super upbeat, super hard-hitting, no pun intended. It’s just really fun and gets you riled up in the best way possible.” - Téa, Guitarist

Find the full version of the song at: https://mmata.lnk.to/HLAG

Reunited at last. 🙌 

Sifa, a refugee who escaped violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo, had not seen her husband Kakule in 7 years – until now. Here in Salt Lake City, Utah the couple and their children are finally together again – and the IRC team who helped make it happens were there for this special, long-awaited moment.

After Americans spoke up, President Biden agreed to welcome more refugees, reuniting families like theirs – and potentially many more – in the safety of the U.S.

This #InternationalDayofFamilies, watch their story and share this video if you, too, stand to make #RefugeesWelcome.
